elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-TITLES:
1. INT. ENCLOSED, CLAUSTROPHOBIC SPACE
THE DEAD MAN IS SHIVERING, DELIRIOUS, SINISTER

I’m a dead man... The rats have left me and I’m all alone. Where are the rats? I’ve got to get out.. He needs to find me, d’you see? Let me out. I’m dead. I can’t be kept in here without the rats. I’m dead!
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 3
2. INT. DRAWING ROOM OF MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE. DAY.
(AT WINDOW) Listen... the birds aren’t singing again. (BEAT, THEN CALLS) Vicomte, I said listen.
(COMING OVER) Madame?
So quiet outside. No birds, still.
It’s just the mist. Sounds do not inform our ears in the usual way; the weather deadens the air.

And my reputation with it. Who will venture out of Paris in such conditions? The glittering salon of the Marquise de Rimdelle! Where once I presided over gatherings of the Highest Society... And who now remains? The unfailing Vicomte de Valdac, already a guest of the house.
You tire of me, perhaps, Madame?

Sulking does not become you, Vicomte. Consider my plight — I have mixed with the most brilliant philosophers, diplomats, politicians and great ladies, and now I barely remember when last I had a— [visitor].
FX: KNOCK AT THE DOOR.
A timely interjection.
My footman. Well, well... (CALLS) Yes, Jean, enter.
FX: DOOR OPENS AND JEAN THE FOOTMAN ENTERS
Your guests have arrived, madame.
(PERKS UP) Guests, Jean? Today? I was not expecting anyone.
The Doctor, madame, and his two young companions.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 4
A doctor! (TEASING) Do the doors of the Marquise de Rimdelle’s salon open now to the bourgeoisie?
I am willing to clutch at any distraction. (TO FOOTMAN) Jean, show our guests to the Blue Room. I shall receive them there.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 5
3. INT. MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE’S RECEPTION ROOM. DAY.
(NB: THE DOCTOR, NYSSA AND HANNAH HAVE FORGOTTEN THEIR TRUE IDENTITIES; HERE THEY BELIEVE THEMSELVES SIMPLE TRAVELLERS ABROAD FROM ENGLAND. )
.. you'll see this reception room is decorated in the Rococo style, Nyssa, hugely popular here in France.
(PREOCCUPIED) Fascinating, Doctor.
I find it over-fussy.
Tastes change, Ms Bartholomew. Here in the year 1770 the writing is on the ornately detailed wall for this fashion. Soon the prevailing style will be...
(FX: UNSETTLING HUM — WE HEAR THIS WHEN A CHARACTER IS REMINDED OF THEIR REAL SELF)
. will be...
Doctor?
I can’t think what I was going to say.
Nor can I. It’s not like you can see into the future, is it?
I wish you could. We would know which soirees were to be dreary and so avoid them.
Really, my dear!
NYSSA and HANNAH laugh
FX: MARQUISE AND VICOMTE ENTER
Well, well! Our mystery guests.
Ah! The Marquise de Rimdelle! Enchante, Madame. And your good friend, the Vicomte de Valdac, I assume. Delighted.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 6
I fear you have me at a disadvantage, monsieur...
Oh, brave heart, Madame, I’m the... (FALTERS) I’m the Doctor. May I present my young ward, Nyssa, and her governess, Hannah Bartholomew.
How do you do?
Charmed, Madame. Monsieur.
Delighted.
I trust your journey here was not too arduous. This most lamentable mist...
Mist?
Simply awful, out there, isn’t it!
Hiding something from our scrutiny...
(POLITE BUT UNCOMFORTABLE LAUGH) Well, now... I’m reluctant to say, Doctor, but you surely must know that admittance to my salon is by personal invitation only...
Er.. You did invite us, Madame. Your letter arrived at our lodgings in Paris. I have it here.
FX: PULLS OUT LETTER. MARQUISE takes it

I believe I would remember... Oh. Yes, of course. (LAUGHS SELF- CONSCIOUSLY) What must you think of me, Doctor! Forgive me, please. I’ve heard Voltaire himself speak most highly of you at court, many times.
I entreat you, forgive me — Doctor, ladies — but I must beg a private word with Madame de Rimdelle.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 7
Do excuse me.
Of course.
FX: VICOMTE AND RIMDELLE EXIT
I hope we have not given offence? I have been looking forward to this visit for.. for as long as I can remember.
To be truthful, I don’t feel very well. A headache.
No, neither do I. Something feels... very wrong.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 8
4. INT. ANTECHAMBER. DAY
(FX: FOOTFALLS ON FLOORBOARDS, SWISH OF SKIRTS ETC AS MARQUISE AND VICOMTE MOVE INTO OUR EARSHOT )
Really, Vicomte, a private conversation in the alcove? How scurrilous. Whatever can be the matter?
(TROUBLED) I’m not sure, Madame. An instinct. I would like to know more about these newcomers.
As would I - there is a most enlightening tool called ‘conversation’, most instructive if well employed.
Did Voltaire really speak to you of the Doctor?
Of course! I cannot understand how inviting him here had slipped my mind. The Doctor studied under Jean Astruc, I understand, and is a most persuasive writer on many subjects in his native England.
He and his companions are foreigners, then. (PAINED) Aliens...?
FX: THE UNSETTLING HUM - VALDAC FIGHTS AGAINST CONDITIONING
Monsieur?
FX: HUM FALTERS AND STOPS

(USUAL SUAVE SELF AGAIN) I... should like to speak alone with the governess, Madame Bartholomew. So robust a bloom deserves cultivation. Perhaps I might escort both governess and pupil to the orangery to see your niece?
Ah! Bid welcome to the Vicomte de Valdac of old!
While Héléne will delight in company her own age, I shall take a private stroll with Madame Bartholomew.
Since Héléne seems to have taken root amongst her precious plants these days, a little distraction may serve her well. Indeed, it may refresh us all. Go about your wicked business,
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 9
then, my dear Vicomte. While I enjoy a private audience with the Doctor.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 10
5. INT. ENCLOSED, CLAUSTROPHOBIC SPACE
THE DEAD MAN, NOT QUITE SO DELIRIOUS

Rats. Are the rats coming back to me..? They’re here. All around. Feeling their way in... trying to change it all. But they can’t change me. I’m dead. I’m a dead man... I won’t be changed. And neither will he. He’s coming. Shhhhhh... the Steamroller Man is coming.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 11
6. EXT: THE GARDENS APPROACHING THE ORANGERY. DAY
(VICOMTE, HANNAH AND NYSSA WALKING OUTSIDE. LAWN UNDERFOOT. THE MIST DEADENS ALL)
The weather is so dismal for August. You should’ve worn a shawl over that pretty dress, Nyssa.
Where are my own clothes, Hannah?
You are a little familiar with your governess, mademoiselle, surely?
(EMBARRASSED) Yes, a little more respect, if you please.
Forgive me, Madame, Vicomte. Oh, my head does hurt.
We have nearly arrived at the orangery. You must rest there.
It would be nice to see a little more of the grounds, monsieur. Beyond the shadows of the trees and topiaries...
They look like sentries in this fog.
Ah, Nyssa, your imagination. Always running away with you.
(FX: VERY FAINT, DISTANT STEAM-PUFFING MECHANICAL SOUND; IT’S THE STEAMROLLER MAN SOUND EFFECT - LIKE AN EVIL ‘IVOR THE ENGINE’. ACCOMPANIED BY A SIMPLE, SINISTER NURSERY-RHYMISH MELODY )
(ALARMED) What’s that?
What’s what? I don’t hear anything.
Listen! In the distance! It sounds like... a machine...
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 12
7. INT. DRAWING ROOM OF MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE. DAY.
Thank you, Jean. Oh, and would you kindly decant a bottle of the ‘57 Bordeaux for this evening? That will be all.
FX: JEAN EXITS AND CLOSES DOOR
I welcome you to my salon, Doctor. The days have been far too quiet of late.
Yes, I have that feeling myself. Better that we travel quickly through life and let our deeds call loudly after us.
Hence your many travels?
Yes.. (DISTRACTED) .. my many, many travels. Fuelled perhaps by a feeling of... not belonging. Have you travelled widely yourself?
Ah, in my youth. I linger near Paris because I am a sick woman.
I’m sorry?
Yes - I long ago fell victim to a colic of cultivation and wit.
(LAUGHS POLITELY) Ah! A condition I’m sure will remain incurable until your dotage.

If that is your professional opinion, Doctor, then I am delighted. (BEAT) You have such a pleasant, open face... but I do not believe such unaffected simplicity to be the index of your mind. You are hiding shadows, I think. I fear Paris has been unkind to you.
On occasion. Some time ago I was there with... (PUZZLED BY MEMORY) with the Mona Lisa.
FX: THE CONDITIONING HUM
Displayed at the Palace of Versailles, of course! You mix with the highest of society!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 13
(PAINED) And I was in Paris again, long before that...
FX: HUM DROPS BUT LINGERS
I apologise for my rudeness, Madame. It’s if something urgent had slipped my thoughts. My very speech seems unfamiliar to my tongue... as do these fine clothes and this powdered wig...
I disagree, monsieur. You cut a fine figure.
I can’t help feeling I’d prefer something with deeper pockets... (BEAT) Hannah.
Madame Bartholomew?
Nyssa and I were travelling together for some time. How did we come to acquire Hannah...?
Well, how does one normally acquire a governess? One asks for recommendations, or one advertises... (DRYLY) There again, it was the feast day of Saint Bartholomew not long ago—
(URGENT) The what?
Saint Bartholomew. Perhaps your namesake governess was sent from celestial circles as a divine gift...?
FX: UNSETTLING HUM BUILDS
The Massacre of St Bartholomew’s Eve. The wolves of Paris... Catherine de Medici... (ALOUD) I was there!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 14
8. EXT: OUTSIDE THE ORANGERY. DAY
VICOMTE, HANNAH AND NYSSA STILL LISTENING OUTSIDE.
A machine, you said, Nyssa?
I hear nothing.
It’s stopped now.
The wind, perhaps? Please, let us keep moving.
(ALARM) What’s that up ahead?
Just the orangery, my dear. I told you it was not far from the
house. Though Héléne rarely leaves its confines.
Why not?
FX: HE OPENS DOOR.
Ah, warmth!
Please. After you, mes dames.
CONTINUES INTO:
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 15
9. INT. ORANGERY. DAY [CONTINUOUS]
(INSIDE, A COAL-FIRED OVEN ROARS. EXOTIC BIRDS CALL AND CLATTER BETWEEN PERCHES )
(ENTERING, CALLS) Héléne? Héléne, it’s Monsieur Valdac. I have brought visitors from England, guests of your aunt! A young lady — Nyssa — and her governess, Hannah Bartholomew.
Is the girl even here?
Sometimes, she likes to hide among her plants. A game she plays. (CALLS) Héléne!
I remember a grove I used to visit in childhood. A grove I was supposed to tend... (BEAT) What are all these cages...?
Exotic birds, my dear. Delicate creatures that would perish in the wild.
So kept prisoners indoors?
For their protection.
Héléne, my dear child, do please come out.
FX: SULLEN FOOTSTEPS AS HELENE COMES OUT
Good day. Please, close the door, the heat’s escaping.
Allow me.
No, please, Mademoiselle. I wish to show Madame Bartholomew a little of the grounds. She expressed an interest...
Certainly, Monsieur.
Héleéne will look after you, Nyssa. We shall return shortly.
FX: THEY EXIT AND DOOR CLOSES
MASQUERADE by
(AWKWARD) I’m pleased
You’re not like them,
Well, I— (don’t know)
Are you?
No. I don’t think so.
Stephen Cole (FINAL)
to meet you, Héléne.
are you?
Well, then. Perhaps we can talk.
Page 16
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 17
10. INT. DRAWING ROOM OF MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE. DAY.
FX: WITH THIS LINE, HUM STOPS
My dear Doctor, the massacre of the Huguenots occurred two hundred years— [ago]
(EPIPHANY) I was there, Madame! August 1572. Coming and going, so many cities since then. So many... worlds!
You are unwell, monsieur!
I am in the wrong place, Madame. Eighteenth century France is not where I belong. (PULLS AT HIS REGENCY-STYLE WIG) And these ridiculous accoutrements are really... not... me!
Your wig, monsieur!
It is not mine. My memories have been suppressed so I would accept Nyssa as my ward and Hannah as my... (SIGHS) No. Hannah shouldn’t be here at all...
Your behaviour offends me, Monsieur. I shall ring for my footman, that he may deal with you. Jean!
FX: SHE RINGS BELL
Good idea! Here, give me the bell, would you?
FX: HE RINGS THE BELL HARDER
You are a madman!
Why have I been stripped of my memories and placed here, hmm? And by whom? Perhaps when Jean arrives he would be kind enough to escort me to my young friends.
He will escort you from the premeses, Monsieur! (CALLS) Jean! Where the devil are you?
(MUTTERS) Where are we al1l...?
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 18
11. EXT. RIMDELLE’S GARDENS. DAY.
(HANNAH AND VICOMTE ARE WALKING. WE HEAR A FOUNTAIN GURGLING IN THE MIDDLE DISTANCE )
Well, Monsieur Vicomte, I must say, you are good company.
You are too kind... Hannah.
Somewhat presumptuous company, as well! I hope you’re not eyeing that pagoda with dubious intent.
(PUZZLED) I have not seen it before. In the Chinese style, would you say?
I’m afraid I wouldn’t know. The style is at odds with the rest of the estate...
Madame de Rimdelle must have built it in secret.
She looks like a lady who’d have secrets. (SHIVERS) But night begins to fall, and this weather is hardly clement. Let us return to the Orangery. Nyssa is supposed to be in my care.
Both she and Héléne are such delicate flowers, they are surely thriving in the warm together. Please, madame. Sit here, on the bench. We may observe the fountain and converse a little longer.
THEY SIT
Tell me. We arrive to find only you, Madame de Rimdelle, that pretty young niece of hers and the footman.. Beyond having a four for bridge, whatever must you do all day?
The days have always passed fast enough, I assure you. There have been so many of us here. Intrigues and affairs, duels and liaisons...
Everything one would expect of high society. What happened to the others?
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 19
The others? Well, it is quiet now, but... Well. Many summer abroad. (AWKWARD BEAT) And how do your days pass, Madame? Travelling with your employer and the young girl, you must own many tales.
Yes. You’d think so, but...
You seem troubled.
Nothing that can be helped by a chivalrous leap to the damsel’s rescue, I’m afraid. Just a feeling there’s something I’m forgetting...
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 20
12. INT. DRAWING ROOM OF MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE. DAY.
FX: URGENT RINGING OF BELL
Oh! Where can Jean be?
I don’t know. There’s much I don’t know at present. Too many blanks... My friends are with this Vicomte de Valdac, yes? Do you know him well?
You said you knew the Vicomte.
And you said Voltaire had spoken of me at court. But Louis the
fifteenth expelled him from Paris in 1758 and banned his return indefinitely. In 1770, Voltaire is comfortably installed at his estate in Ferney.
But I clearly remember him telling— (me)

A suggestion placed in your mind! It has to be. Just like my journey here, or my believing I knew the vicomte, or my thinking Nyssa and Hannah and I belong in this time. Certain convenient pieces of information have been placed in our minds. Like cover stories, you see?
Preposterous! You have lost your reason— (monsieur)
Someone wants my friends and I out of the way - stranded here in a backwater of eighteenth-century France. Wants us to forget who we are. But why? Why here?
I am asking myself the same question, believe me. (RINGS AGAIN) Jean! Oh, this is insufferable. Now I must hunt down my own servants. You will remain here, Monsieur.
MARQUISE EXITS
Madame... Madame, wait! (FOLLOWS HER)
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 21
13. INT. ORANGERY. DAY
So, Nyssa. Who are you?
Well, Héléne... I am the ward of the Doctor, an English physician. I have accompanied him to France to build on my education, and to enhance my social standing. My tutor is Hannah— (Bartholomew)
You speak as if by rote! These are dry details. I see in your eyes that, once, you felt life to be an adventure.
Yes.
I felt that way too. Now, I prefer to cultivate plants and tiny birds over acquaintances.
You are very successful. The plants are thriving, the birds
happy.

They alone. (SIGHS) I see the Marquise and the Vicomte titter and flirt their way through the empty days without a care - like half-sketched characters in a wit’s reminiscence. But so many of the servants have left, so few visitors come to call. Since the mist fell, no one has come. No one besides you.
When did the weather change?
I.. I don’t know. But.. so much is changing. I know it.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 22
14. INT. ENCLOSED, CLAUSTROPHOBIC SPACE

(MIMICS) ‘I know it! I know it!’ But you don’t know ME! None of you... You’re waking up. Coming back to your senses, oh dear, dear, dear... Coming back to me, rats. (SHOUTS) Hello! Hello, I’m here! I’m here! Now, help me!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 23
15. INT. HALL OF MARQUISE DE RIMDELLE. DAY.
FX: DOCTOR FOLLOWING MARQUISE THROUGH HALL
I need your help, Madame. Anything you can tell me about those who come and go here might trigger a memory that’s been repressed... in both our minds, perhaps!
I tire of these foolish imaginings, Doctor. I asked you wait in my drawing room, not follow me about the hall like a lost animal. Jean!
FX: SHE RINGS BELL. DOCTOR STOPS BELL
Stop that, would you? I think we’ve established that wherever he is, Jean is not within earshot. (BEAT) Can you recall how long you’ve lived here?
The chateau has been in my family’s possession for centuries. (SARCASTIC) Of course, as a traveller in time, you are welcome to check.
Alas, my means of travel has been taken from me. A large blue box, I believe. It’s on the tip of my mind, but... (SIGHS) Tell me - where should Jean be now?
Well... I told him to decant some wine for dinner this evening. From the cellar.
That’s as good a place to look as any, then. Shall we, Madame?
Oh... very well.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 24
16. INT. ORANGERY. DAY.
(HOPEFUL) It’s not just me, is it, Nyssa? You feel there’s something wrong too?
Oh, Héleéne... I’ve felt strange ever since the Doctor brought us here. Disturbed by something I can’t quite remember. And the noise outside...
FX: DISTANT STEAMROLLER MAN MACHINERY
There! Do you hear it?
The mechanical noise?
Yes. Just faintly.
(HUSHED) I’ve heard it before. In the space between the shadows, some uncanny machine, always distant, moving at the fringes of the estate. Circling the house... Watching...
What is it?
There’s a name that creeps into my thoughts when the noise comes... The Steamroller Man.
Steamroller Man...?
In the space between the shadows... I cannot explain it. But this Steamroller Man... a little louder each time... I think he’s coming closer.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 25
17. EXT. RIMDELLE’S GARDENS. NIGHT
(FX: FOUNTAIN GURGLES FAINTLY BUT NOTICEABLY IN B/G. SLOWLY, THE SOUND OF THE STEAMROLLER MAN GETS LOUDER — AS HE GETS CLOSER)
Goodness, Vicomte, how long have we been talking? Night is falling. We should return.
You still seem troubled, Hannah. The thoughts that will not come...?
Yes.
Consider: though this mist around us will hide the moon from our sight, we know that she shines on. In the same way...
I grasp the allusion, thank you. But the moon... The crescent moon... (HESITANT, REMEMBERING) Now... is simply our moment in Time’s limelight.
Excuse me?
FX: THE UNSETTLING HUM
I have always believed that one day we shall leave our bodies, become spirits of the shadows. Guide others while they bask in the living moment...
Perhaps, Madame, you have moved beyond your mortal form already.
SINISTER MUSIC STAB
What?
After all, you have the countenance of an angel, do you not?
(FX: HUM BREAKS OFF. SOUND OF STEAMROLLER MAN IS V AUDIBLE, IT’S NEARING THE FOUNTAIN IN BACKGROUND )
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 26
(LAUGHS) Really, monsieur. Such fulsome flattery ill-becomes either of us.. (TAILS OFF) Listen.
(FX: STEAMROLLER MAN CRASHES THROUGH FOUNTAIN. STONE SMASHES, WATER STOPS GURGLING, STONE IS CRUSHED INTO LAWN)
Listen, how quiet it is. No birds. No wind.
(FX: PATENTLY IT IS NOT SILENT. THE STEAMROLLER MAN STILL SLOWLY APPROACHING, UNDER: )
Shall we return to the Orangery?
Very well, Madame.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 27
18. INT. CELLAR, RIMDELLE’S HOUSE. DAY
FX: CLASSIC DAMP CELLAR, OCCASIONAL SQUEAK OF RATS
Hmm. We could use more light down here.
It is a cellar, Doctor. Windows are somewhat troublesome to install.
These candle stubs won’t last us long. You don’t have any oil lamps?
We need Jean to fetch some.
(SUDDENLY WE HEAR DEAD MAN SPEAKING, MUFFLED AS THOUGH THROUGH A WALL CLOSE BY)
Fetch... He’s coming... He knows it’s not right.
Jean?
He’s coming here. Smash it all down. Level this place.
Jean, is that you?
Whom do you hear? I hear no one.
(DOCTOR AND MARQUISE SPEAK OVER DEAD MAN’S RAVING SPEECH

Smash it down! Smash the whole place down. Where are the rats? I’ve got to get out... find him, d’you see? I have to! Let me out. Get me out. I’m dead. I can’t be kept in here. I’m dead. I need the rats, I’m dead. (REPEAT IF NECESSARY )
You can’t hear that?!
I can hear rats. Filthy things. How did you persuade me to venture here...?
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 28
I heard a man’s voice. He sounds in great distress. But where is he..? (CALLS) Hello! Do you know where you are?
Do you know where you are? No rats. Know where you are.
Is he mimicking...?
(ICY) I feel this jest to be in very poor taste.
Madame, there IS a voice. It could be Jean!
Jean? (BLANK) Who is Jean?
PAUSE
(ASTONISHED) Your footman. The servant we’ve been looking for.
I have no Jean on my staff. Besides, I have given my servants leave for a day. (BLUSTERS) One... one cannot relish privilege until one knows what it means to be without it.
(URGENT) No. No, think, Madame. We rang for Jean when we were in the drawing room. He didn’t appear so we went looking. Why do you think we’re here, now?
Enough, monsieur. I would ask that you depart my house.
Depart! If he finds me, we’ll depart. Dead man’s! Dead...
I have to find this man, and Nyssa and Hannah.
I’m going to fetch the Vicomte. I will have you ejected from the property, monsieur!
SHE STORMS AWAY.
(BELLOWS) You shouldn’t be here! He’s on his way!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 29
(CALLS AFTER MARQUISE): Madame de Rimdelle, I believe we are all in great danger!
You! Listen to a dead man. The steamroller man is com-
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 30
19. INT. ORANGERY. NIGHT.
Héléne, I think we should find the Doctor and tell him about this Steamroller Man - or whatever it is.

(DISTANT) Night is falling. The grounds, the house, all we know as familiar turns to shadow. And something holds us in this shadow-space, Nyssa. Cultivating us, just as I cultivate these plants and birds... You feel it too, don’t you? Something that once was minding us... now, it’s changing.
Héléne, I don’t understand...
It’s turning the shadows themselves against us.
FX: DOOR THROWN OPEN. RIMDELLE ENTERS
NYSSA AND HELENE BOTH JUMP
Madame de Rimdelle!
Héléne, where is the Vicomte?
Out walking in the shadows with the other one.
With Madame Bartholomew. I must find him.
Madame, what is wrong?
Your guardian thinks he can make an idiot of me. Well, he cannot. You are to leave my property, forthwith!
I don’t understand?
FX: DOOR OPENS AS VICOMTE AND HANNAH ENTER
We heard raised voices...
Hannah! Are you all right?
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 31
Nyssa, kindly remember I’m your governess!
She has no respect, Madame Bartholomew — much like your employer.
FX: UNSETTLING HUM
No! These relationships aren’t real. We don’t belong in this place.
She’s right. We don’t belong...
The children are becoming hysterical.
As has the Doctor. Vicomte, I need your assistance in removing that man from my house.
Madame?
He has abused my hospitality, questioned me as though I were a criminal of the third estate and now runs amok upstairs, calling out to shadows. I believe him quite mad.
No!
FX: QUIETLY, THE APPROACH OF THE STEAMROLLER MAN
Please, madame, monsieur, hold a moment—
How dare you seek to direct me!
HELENE IS CHANGING TO ‘HELEN’, A MORE COMMANDING PERSONALITY
HELENE/HELEN: (SHOUTS) Enough!
ALL ARE SILENCED
HELENE/HELEN:
This whole thing is shot to hell. Valdac, Rimdelle, get out of here! (BEAT) Out!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 32
Yes. I’m sorry.
Forgive us, Héléne.
Come on, Nyssa.
THEY LEAVE
They obeyed you...
This is your doing. You shouldn’t be here.
I don’t understand.
Follow the others. Move!
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 33
20A. EXT: GROUNDS OUTSIDE ORANGERY. NIGHT.
(FX STEAMROLLER MAN SLOWLY CLOSING IN AS NYSSA, HANNAH and HELENE LEAVE THE ORANGERY (DOOR SQUEAKS ETC) )
Whatever’s making that noise, it’s close.
Noise?
There’s nothing!
HELENE /HELEN: There’s the Steamroller Man.
(AFRAID; SIGNIFICANT) The Steamroller Man...
HELENE/HELEN:
Perhaps two hundred metres — and closing. Damn this fog, can’t see. Rimdelle, Valdac — and you two, Nyssa and Bartholomew, whoever the hell you are — I say we regroup at the house.
Well, really! A little courtesy— [costs nothing]
Vicomte! Behind the trees, there. I think something moved.
FX: RUSTLE OF BRANCHES
Nyssa! Hannah!
Doctor!
Thank goodness you’re safe.
Safe? Why shouldn’t we be?
Doctor! You confront and confound me wherever I turn.
Reluctantly, I assure you. Now please, all of you, we must return to the house and find whoever’s trapped in the cellar.
MASQUERADE by Stephen Cole (FINAL) Page 34
